title: Stocks rise as earnings reports temper bets on rate rises
text:
Stock markets rose on Tuesday and government debt yields increased as traders balanced optimism about corporate earnings with the prospect of central banks lifting interest rates.

Wall Street's S&P 500 index closed 0.7 per cent higher in New York; the technology-focused Nasdaq Composite also ended the day up 0.7 per cent. The Stoxx Europe 600 index closed up 0.3 per cent.

The consumer goods bellwether Procter & Gamble warned of rising input costs earlier in the day, but maintained its full-year earnings forecast. Shares in P&G ceded 1.2 per cent to $140.66.

Signs that companies were managing inflationary pressures would prompt traders to top up on equities, analysts said, especially as bond markets remained vulnerable to central banks' monetary tightening signals.

“There is dispersion between central banks about the pace of monetary tightening,” said Salman Baig, multi-asset investment manager at Unigestion. “But markets are pricing in US rate hikes. It makes equities more resilient because there are fewer reasons to be in bonds.”

The FTSE All-World share index, which was driven more than 4 per cent lower in September, has recouped almost all of those losses so far this month.

In bond markets, the yield on the 10-year US Treasury note — which moves inversely to its price — rose to 1.64 per cent, its highest trading level since May.

Minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting suggested the US central bank might begin reducing its $120bn a month of coronavirus-driven bond purchases as soon as next month. Financial markets are also pricing in the first pandemic-era rate rise from the central bank — which pulled borrowing costs down to zero at the peak of the coronavirus crisis in March 2020 — for September next year.

Supply chain bottlenecks and the rising cost of energy, food and rents have kept US headline consumer price inflation higher than 5 per cent for four months. But in the minutes of their latest meeting, Fed policymakers continued to describe the surge as “transitory”.

Andrew Bailey, Bank of England governor, has taken a different tone, saying over the weekend that the UK central bank would “have to act” on price pressures. The latest UK inflation data will be released on Wednesday.

“The BoE is taking a way firmer stance than many other central banks,” said Salman Ahmed, global head of macro at Fidelity International.

“Whether that thinking is correct, we don't know, it could be that they kill the [post-pandemic] economic recovery,” he added, if rising debt costs combined with surging commodity prices hit consumer spending.

The yield on the UK's 10-year government was last up 0.03 percentage points to 1.16 per cent.

Meanwhile, the dollar dropped against leading currencies as traders wagered on central banks outside the US raising interest rates before the Fed moves to increase borrowing costs.

The dollar index, which measures the greenback against six peers, fell to its lowest level since late September, but retraced some of those losses by mid-afternoon in New York. It was last down 0.2 per cent.

Sterling rose by 0.5 per cent against the dollar to $1.38 as investors placed further bets on the BoE raising rates by Christmas to battle inflation.

Ahmed said the dollar would remain “the antidote to fragility” in equity and bond markets as investors remained fearful about inflation causing an economic slowdown.

A survey of 430 fund managers by Bank of America found that their cash holdings jumped to a year high of 4.7 per cent of assets in October as participants' global growth expectations turned negative for the first time since April last year.
